title_sort: william e. vandemark to walt whitman, 31 july 1863
title: William E. Vandemark to Walt Whitman, 31 July 1863
text: Friend witman[Whitman]I now take the plesure[pleasure] of fulfilling my promace[promise] of writing to yo[you] hoping to find yo en Joying good hlth I am not very well i am worse now than wen i got out of bed i tore my wound acoming[a-coming] home the hole is a bout half an inch square I hante ben noware sence i[I] have been home i[I] have had the docter and he ordered me to bathe in sider soaky i[I] will hef[have] to have my furlow[furlough] exstended[extended] I would have written be fore but i was not able to do it yo[youth] must exscuse[excuse] me—the crops look much better here than they do in washington[Washington] I find a grate[great] many that donte know me when i arrived in york[York] my cosin[cousin] was thare[there] and he brought me to my home it has ben[been] rainy ever since I have been home—give my love to the boys in ward B I will be back Just as soon as i am able to comeNo more at present Good by answer by return mail from a friend and ever shall be William E. Vandemark to Walt Whitman, 31 July 1863
